repnme.cdata!:
Honduras - First Poverty Reduction Support
            Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the First Poverty Reduction
            Support Credit (PRSC) Project for Honduras were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was moderate, the Bank performance was
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: to improve
            predictability of resource flow, PRSC operations can be
            designed such that the timing of the tranche release is held
            constant while the amount is adjusted in line with borrower
            performance. The non-approval of the PRSC-II operation
            suggests that this instrument has not yet been able to
            deliver on the promise of greater predictability in the
            annual resource flow made available to Honduras. In
            response, International Development Association (IDA) has
            been preparing a new budget support operation that seeks to
            keep the timing predictable, but adjusting the credit amount
            according to the number and substance of the triggers
            achieved within that pre-determined period. Effective donor
            coordination during the formulation of policy conditionality
            reduces the danger of providing conflicting policy advice.
            Staff of the Bank, International Monetary Fund (IMF),
            Inter-American Development Bank (IDB) and bilateral donors
            consulted regularly on policy matters relating to poverty
            reduction strategy (PRS) implementation in Honduras during
            program preparation. Program design should be simple
            (limiting the amount of triggers) and targets should be
            realistic, particularly where political consensus is
            lacking, such as during pre-election periods. In such cases,
            it is often better to focus on consolidating existing gains
            and avoiding policy reversals.

repnme.cdata!: Honduras - First Poverty Reduction Support Credit

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome for the First Poverty
            Reduction Support Credit (PRSC) for Honduras was
            satisfactory, the sustainability was satisfactory, the
            institutional development impact was satisfactory, and the
            Bank and borrower performance were both satisfactory.
            Lessons learned from the project: The limited experience
            obtained from the first PRSC operation for Honduras tends to
            support many of the findings reported in the Bank's
            recent PRSC stocktaking report. The experience with PRSC-I
            draws attention to the importance of maintaining good
            coordination with the IMF in the formulation of policy
            conditionalities. PRSC-I was prepared mainly with Bank staff
            that also was involved in the preparation of investment
            operations in the various sectors focused on in the PRSC
            policy matrix. The experience with PRSC-I indicates that it
            is important to be realistic in setting program targets and,
            especially, to avoid being overly ambitious in the period
            before elections. Finally, the non-enforcement of the
            ministerial resolution issued by the health ministry in
            compliance with a Board presentation condition for PRSC-I
            would be tantamount to a policy reversal if left unaddressed.

repnme.cdata!: Honduras - Poverty Reduction Support Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This program document describes a
            single-tranche Poverty Reduction Support Credit (PRSC) to
            the Republic of Honduras for SDR 40.54 million, which
            includes an original amount of SDR 38.6 million (US$56
            million equivalent) and a supplemental credit in the amount
            of SDR 1.94 million (US$2.8 million equivalent).  The main
            objective of the PRS, which analyzes the causes of poverty
            and encompasses reforms and investment programs in a broad
            range of sectors, is to reduce poverty by 24 percentage
            points over the period 2001-2015. Overall, the Poverty
            Reduction Strategy Paper (PRSP) and the associated first
            Progress Report (PRSP-PR), which was discussed by the Board
            in February 2004, present a strategy to reduce poverty in
            Honduras. The strategy itself is structured around six
            pillars: (1) accelerating equitable and sustainable growth
            to levels consistent with the income poverty reduction
            targets; (2) reducing rural poverty; (3) reducing urban
            poverty; (4) enhancing investment in human capital; 5)
            strengthening social protection for specific vulnerable
            groups; and (6) ensuring the sustainability of the strategy
            through governance and institutional reforms and enhanced
            environmental sustainability. In line with these pillars,
            the PRSC aims to support Government's efforts to:
            accelerate pro-poor growth, via support for reforms aimed at
            increasing competitiveness and maximizing the potential for
            new investment and employment-creation for men and   women
            in both urban and rural areas in the wake of new regional
            and international agreements, in particular, the Central
            America Free Trade Agreement (CAFTA); increase the impact
            and efficiency of resources devoted to human development and
            social protection, with a focus on deconcentration of
            responsibilities for service provision and increased
            empowerment of beneficiaries of key services; and increase
            the medium- and long-term sustainability of poverty
            reduction initiatives through policy and institutional
            reforms geared to strengthening governance and public sector
            management and improving management of the environment,
            particularly in Honduras' extensive protected areas. In
            addition, the PRSC will support the Government's
            initiatives to systematize consultation processes around the
            poverty reduction strategy and strengthen monitoring and
            evaluation at national and community levels.
